TITLE V--TAX PROVISIONS

SEC. 500. SHORT TITLE; ETC.

This title may be cited as the "Small Business Jobs Tax Relief Act of 2010". Amendment of 1986 Code. Whenever an amendment or repeal is mentioned in this title, it refers to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The table of contents includes provisions for small business tax incentives such as temporary exclusion of gain on certain small business stock and limitations on penalties reporting. Subtitle B of the Small Business Jobs Tax Relief Act of 2010 includes provisions related to revenue, such as an increase in deductions for start-up expenditures and the treatment of nonrecourse small business investment company loans. Additionally, benefits under the Small Business Borrower Assistance Program are excluded from gross income. Subtitle A of the Small Business Tax Incentives includes provisions such as a temporary exclusion of 100 percent of gain on certain small business stock. The amendment to section 1202 allows for a special 100 percent exclusion for qualified small business stock acquired between March 15, 2010, and January 1, 2012. Additionally, there are conforming amendments related to the exclusion percentages and dates. The amendments made by this section introduce a "Special 75 percent exclusion" for stock acquired after March 15, 2010. SEC. 511. LIMITATION ON PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO DISCLOSE CERTAIN INFORMATION. SEC. 511 amends subsection (b) of section 6707A to specify the amount of penalty for failure to disclose reportable transactions. The penalty is 75 percent of the tax decrease shown on the return due to the transaction, with a maximum of $200,000 for listed transactions and $50,000 for other reportable transactions. The penalty for failure to disclose reportable transactions is specified in section 6707A, with a minimum penalty of $10,000 ($5,000 for individuals) and a maximum of $200,000 for listed transactions and $50,000 for other reportable transactions. The amendment applies to penalties assessed after December 31, 2006. SEC. 512. ANNUAL REPORTS ON PENALTIES AND CERTAIN OTHER ENFORCEMENT ACTIONS. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue must submit an annual report to Congress on penalties assessed by the IRS under various provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, including accuracy-related penalties, promoting abusive tax shelters, and failure to furnish information on reportable transactions. The annual report to Congress must include information on penalties assessed by the IRS under different provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, such as accuracy-related penalties, promoting abusive tax shelters, and failure to maintain lists of advisees with respect to reportable transactions. The report must also detail actions taken under specific sections of the Code and any extensions of time for tax assessment. The first report is due by December 31, 2010. SEC. 521 increases the deduction limit for start-up expenditures for taxable years beginning in 2010 or 2011. SEC. 522 treats nonrecourse small business investment company loans from the Small Business Administration as amounts at risk. The amendment to section 465(b)(6) defines qualified nonrecourse financing as financing that is qualified real property financing or qualified SBIC financing, with no personal liability for repayment and not convertible debt. Qualified real property financing is defined as financing borrowed by the taxpayer for holding real property, secured by real property used in the activity, and obtained from a qualified person or government entity. The term "qualified SBIC financing" refers to financing borrowed by a small business investment company from the Small Business Administration. Amendments are made to section 465(b)(6) by removing language related to holding real property. Amendments are made to section 465(b)(6) by removing language related to holding real property in qualified SBIC financing. The effective date for these amendments applies to loans and guarantees made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 523 amends Part III of subchapter B of chapter 1 by adding a new section, SEC. 139F, which excludes benefits under the Small Business Borrower Assistance Program from gross income. Gross income excludes payments made by the Small Business Administration for borrowers under the Small Business Borrower Assistance program. No deduction allowed for interest covered by the payment, and payments reducing loan principal must be allocated among financed expenditures. Payments made by the Small Business Administration under the Small Business Borrower Assistance program must be allocated among financed expenditures, with no deduction allowed for interest covered by the payment. The adjusted basis of property acquired with such expenditure shall be reduced accordingly. Subtitle B of the Revenue Provisions requires a minimum 10-year term for Grantor Retained Annuity Trusts. The amendments in this section apply to payments made after the enactment of the Act. The amendments in this section require a minimum 10-year term for Grantor Retained Annuity Trusts, with additional requirements for grantor retained annuities. The amendments require a 10-year term for Grantor Retained Annuity Trusts, with fixed amounts not decreasing annually for the first 10 years, and the remainder interest must have a value greater than zero at the time of transfer. Effective for transfers made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 532 amends section 40(b)(6)(E) to make crude tall oil with an acid number greater than 25 ineligible for cellulosic biofuel producer credit. Effective January 1, 2010. SEC. 533 increases the percentage for payment of corporate estimated taxes by 7.75 points under the Hiring Incentives to Restore Employment Act.
